awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Systems Approach Toward Understanding the Diversification of Tropane and Granatane Alkaloid Biosynthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to use comparative approaches to investigate the synthesis pathways of two organic, nitrogen containing compounds in three different plant families to discover new genes and test the hypothesis that these two pathways developed independently of one another in each family. These alkaloids defend plants against insects and other pests and pathogens, and are used by humans as flavourings, fragrances, pesticides and medicines. This research will provide multiple opportunities for interdisciplinary training in genomics, structural biology, biochemistry, and analytical chemistry to graduate and undergraduate students.  Furthermore, graduate student training will be enhanced through implementation of exchanges between partner labs to facilitate the development of interdisciplinary skills. Formal undergraduate exchanges will be accomplished by the recruitment of female and underrepresented minority students from Texas Tech or Iowa State University into a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Program at Michigan State University.  The project also will work directly with a local Community College in Iowa to provide Community College students with exposure to structural biology.

Tropane and granatane alkaloids contain a core bicyclic ring structure and appear scattered across unrelated plant families.  The research project will utilize a top down approach of combined transcriptomics and metabolomics coupled with comparative functional, biochemical and structural biology based approaches to elucidate the pathways and mechanisms that underlie the biosynthesis of the pharmaceutically important tropane and granatane alkaloids. Gene discovery will occur in three distinct and important crop families: Brassicaceae, Lythraceae and Erythroxylaceae and the resulting data will be compared to an established tropane pathway in the Solanaceae. This comparative approach will be used to test the hypothesis that novel biocatalytic activities within the tropane biosynthetic pathways of distinct species are the source of the independent emergence of the tropane alkaloid system within the plant lineage. Additionally, the research explores the possibility that the different components of tropane alkaloid metabolism were independently co-opted to build new metabolic systems (e.g. granatane alkaloids). Overall, this approach will lead to enhanced understanding of tropane and granatane alkaloid biosynthesis. Moreover, knowledge of the biosynthetic steps leading to tropane and granatane alkaloids is crucial for quantitative modeling and metabolic engineering of these pharmacologically active chemicals.

por.por_cntn:
Collectively, plants synthesize hundreds of thousands of small chemically distinct metabolites that function within the host plant as attractants to promote beneficial interactions with associated organisms or as repellants and toxins to discourage pathogens, insects or herbivores. These chemicals are often referred to as specialized metabolites and have been harnessed by humans for millennia for use as flavorings, fragrances, bio-pesticides, narcotics and medicines. However, the pathways leading to the biosynthesis of the vast majority of plant specialized metabolites remain unresolved, which frequently limits their sustainable production and harnessing of their biocatalytic potential to develop new chemicals. This project, part of a larger collaborative effort, focused on identifying the structural basis by which tropane alkaloids, a metabolic system found in a limited number of plant families, have emerged and evolved in plants.

At the beginning of this project, a critical step for tropane alkaloid biosynthesis had been reported to involved a type III polyketide synthase, however the atypical nature of the proposed biochemical reaction resulted in significant uncertainty about the function of this enzyme. Collaborators from Texas Tech University, Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (Gatersleben, Germany) and Michigan State University identified candidate genes for tropane alkaloid associated type III polyketides synthases from two plant families known to make tropane alkaloid, namely Solanaceae and Erythroxylaceae. Upon obtaining these genes, our group was successful in obtaining the 3D crystal structure of each candidate gene. Knowledge of the 3D structure was then used to design mutants which allowed us to probe and elucidate the mechanisms of action of these enzymes. Overall these research activities elucidated a previously unknown biochemical activity of the type III polyketide synthase family and indicated that tropane alkaloids has evolved multiple times independently.

 

Next, our collaborators identified a set of spermidine synthase-related genes, one of the last remaining enzymatic steps to be identified. Once received, our group performed a structural analysis of these candidate-genes. To our surprise, our structural analyses combined with collaborators functional analyses revealed a hitherto unknown metabolic step in tropane alkaloid biosynthesis. Furthermore, this new metabolic step results from a previously unknown biocatalytic activity of these spermidine synthase-related genes.  

Taken together, the knowledge gained from research supported by this project has not only resolved long standing uncertainties related to tropane alkaloid biosynthesis but has also unveiled previously unknown biochemical transformations. We have been able to show that tropane alkaloid evolved independently in different plant families. Additionally, with data generated as part of this NSF grant we have the fundamental knowledge and tools necessary for a full biochemical reconstruction of the tropane alkaloid pathway in both microorganisms and in plants which are normally not capable of making this class of metabolites.

Outside of research results, this project has had a number of broader impacts. First, portions of this project contributed to the doctoral dissertation of one graduate student who has successfully completed her studies and is now employed as an industry scientist. Secondly, two undergraduate students from underrepresented STEM populations were employed as laboratory assistants. Thirdly, regular outreach activities with a community college and youth summer program were conducted. Lastly, a brochure was developed targeting high school students interested in STEM fields and their teachers. This brochure, available in English and Spanish language versions, discussed career paths in structural biology as well as research topics related to this project.
